options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: met on VR headset in AltSpace VR
None

There was not much lecturing in class. We mostly had multiple assignments going at once and either presented them in class for critiques or worked on them during class and shared screen when it was our turn for feedback during the process.
Virtual Reality, In class Workshops/labs

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of software and am better at drawing and creating compositions.
Familiarity with software, basic drawing abilities, and the ability to think and discuss visually.

I learned some basic drawing techniques like plumb lines, weight, and shading. We also discussed the formal elements and perspective and applied all of these to various art forms including: Photoshop, Illustrator, collaging, animation, laser cutting, sculpting/modeling, virtual reality, iPad drawing, and more.
We learned about a lot of modes of drawing and making art that could make use of digital products and media.
I got a great foundational understanding of drawing, and also got to explore drawing in several different digital mediums

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved how each project used its own software and had its own twist. However, we got behind and overlapping projects was counterproductive to my artistic process.

The course was a great class to introduce basic drawing concepts. However, the class almost felt like an adaptation of basic drawing to the digital space, rather than a course teaching digital-specific drawing techniques. Also, I felt we had too many critiques and having more in-class drawing sessions would be more engaging and helpful. Also, we moved super quickly and many, many ideas were introduced, so I feel like I did not have as much time to polish every piece.

Maybe using the break out rooms and sending us out into pairs to discuss art pieces then come back and chat as a group to facilitate more student engagement and speaking and to get us to know our classmates more since it is hard when we are remote.

This course tried to do so much and in the end I found that I did not produce a lot of work that I was proud of or wanted to show. It was great that we had a great breadth of tools that we knew about, but we never spent a lot of time on one of them so we ended up using Illustrator for many weeks, but only getting instruction or the chance to use one or two of the tools/skillsets for it for assignments specifically for class. I felt like my sketchbook was a better use of my time and I enjoyed working on that a lot more than the specific class assignments we were given. It was also really chaotic to have everyone trying to share their screens at the same time while also working in another application on our laptop and also having the professor try and show us something, but Im not sure how that could be avoided over zoom.
Worked very well in the Zoom landscape

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class went from a digital/studio class to a purely digital class. It succeeded because it is a class firmly rooted in the digital and it was easy to transition to zoom given yale's resources to equip students with the necessary hardware (drawing tablet, VR headset).

The professor tried very hard to make this experience similar to an in-class experience. It worked for the most part, but sharing our screen over Zoom was a little messy, and I think using different software potentially would work more for a class like this. Including traditional modes of art-making in addition to digital was annoying for the students off-campus, as it was difficult to get and work with the material without a dedicated space. Submission of traditional pieces was also difficult without a dedicated camera or photography space.
Utilizing screen sharing and getting it to work with the Oculus Quests was a great idea. It was helpful to be able to screenshare while working to get real-time feedback.

If the course is going to be 2 hours twice a week, I think it would be better to have a more regular schedule of things, like spending one day doing a tutorial or working collaboratively on a project and getting feedback on something the next day and trying to apply it. Sometimes class would go way over 2 hours for a critique where barely anyone spoke and other times we would end an hour early because only one thing was planned and it wasnt able to be done over zoom
Using Zoom and virtual reality to have classes was really successful, lots of students were engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. I loved the course and thought it was really fun to draw digitally. However, I would recommend they buy an iPad. I did not have an iPad and was perhaps the only kid in the class without one; not being able to use Procreate, an exclusive iPad app, for various projects felt limiting.

For people aiming to get better at drawing in general, this class is a great alternative for basic drawing. However, for people who want a more focused class on digital specific drawing skills, I don't think this class is for you. You will definitely become a better artist after this class.

This is a great course for someone who wants to explore art in many forms for short periods of time and then choose which ones they want to pursue further. It was a good appetizer of many art styles, but we also discussed formal elements along the way.
If you want to learn a lot about a few digital media tools, then no. If you just want a breadth of knowledge about what is out there, then its fine.
Yes, this was a really fun course where I got to explore lots of aspects of drawing through a number of media, such as virtual reality, Photoshop, Procreate, etc.
Definitely!! such an amazing artistic outlet to have in my semester. I got such a valuable art education in this class.
